Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2010, the observatory at Summit, Greenland, in the center of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS), was expanded to include a comprehensive suite of cloud-atmosphere observing instruments including microwave and infrared spectrometers, cloud radar, depolarization lidar, ceilometer, precipitation sensor, sodar, and a twice-daily radiosonde program. This observing effort was termed ICECAPS (Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit). A continuation of this project is proposed here, with moderate enhancements to include atmospheric aerosol observations. Measurements from this expanded instrument suite will be used to derive critical baseline atmospheric data products including:
* Atmospheric State - tropospheric temperature, moisture, and wind profiles
* Aerosols - concentration of total particles and cloud condensation nuclei
* Cloud Macrophysics - occurrence, vertical boundaries, temperature
* Cloud Microphysics - phase, water content, and characteristic particle size
* Precipitation - type and rate
Together these products, when combined with similar ongoing measurements at Summit, can be used to study processes that impact the surface energy budget and precipitation at the site, as well as addressing questions related to atmospheric stability, cloud phase composition, the persistence of stratiform clouds, and aerosol-cloud interactions. It is further anticipated that these observations will continue to be used by a broad cross-section of the scientific community to promote understanding of GIS and Arctic climate, validate satellite observations, and evaluate model simulations. Graduate students play significant roles in most aspects of this project, gaining valuable experience with polar field work, operating instruments, and processing data. In addition, this research team has developed a unique education and outreach plan to work with students from local schools using simple, proxy instrumentation to help develop their understanding of atmospheric principles and observations, and to enhance the scientific curriculum in their schools via a wide range of outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation supported a long-term observation program called the Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS) Project.  ICECAPS deployed an extensive array of in-situ and advanced ground-based remote sensors to Summit Station in the center of the Greenland Ice Sheet in July 2010 to make detailed observations of cloud and precipitation properties, the thermodynamic and kinematic evolution of the troposphere, and downwelling radiative energy at the surface.  The ICECAPS project is currently scheduled to continue collecting these observations at least until the summer of 2020. The project reported on here covers the period 2014 - 2019.

This research was conducted by a research team that spanned across six universities (U Colorado, Washington State U, U Wisconsin-Madison, Vanderbilt U, U Oklahoma, U Idaho), and included researchers from national laboratories such as NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory and DOE?s Argonne National Laboratory.  In addition, 15 graduate students at these universities were involved in this research.  These students gained valuable insights into Arctic processes, experience working with observational data, developing and applying higher-order data processing algorithms, and conducting scientific analyses. Many of these students have also spent time in the field, which has enriched their graduate education experience and will support their development as young scientists.

To date, over 30 scientific papers have been published as part of this project.  Some of the high-level research accomplishments include:

  • Development of the first comprehensive observationally-based characterization of the surface energy budget at Summit, and how the different components (e.g., radiation, sensible heating, etc) evolve over the annual cycle
  • Performed an in-depth study of the melt event in July 2012, wherein over 95% of the Greenland ice sheet experienced melting, and demonstrated the critical role that liquid-bearing clouds played in enhancing the radiative energy at the surface that contributed to the melt
  • Characterized the snowfall rates and properties at Summit, and how the snowfall changes with large scale weather patterns
  • Investigated how the lifetime and microphysical properties of long-lived mixed-phase clouds depends on the large-scale mesoscale environment
  • Characterized the downwelling spectral infrared radiative flux at Summit, and how a model reanalysis compares with the ICECAPS observations
  • Improved the accuracy of liquid water absorption models in the microwave, which greatly improves the accuracy of space-based observations of cloud properties
